questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with fatigue and pallor. Her reticulocyte count is 5%, hemoglobin is 9 g/dL, and hematocrit is 28%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3.0%.

 

Option B:

 

The corrected reticulocyte count is calculated by multiplying the reticulocyte count by the ratio of the patient's hemoglobin to a normal hemoglobin (15 g/dL for males, 14 g/dL for females). In this case, the corrected reticulocyte count is 5% * (9/14) = 3.2%.

 

Educational objective:

 

The corrected reticulocyte count adjusts for the degree of anemia, providing a more accurate reflection of bone marrow activity.

choices.text: Serum B12 and folate levels

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of heavy alcohol use presents with macrocytic anemia on a routine blood test. His MCV is 105 fL and his RPI is 3.5. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum B12 and folate levels

 

Option B:

 

This is the most direct and cost-effective way to assess for deficiencies in these vitamins, which are common causes of macrocytic anemia, especially in patients with a history of alcohol abuse

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hemoglobin electrophoresis: This test is used to identify abnormal types of hemoglobin, as seen in conditions like sickle cell disease or thalassemia. It is not helpful in diagnosing vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

 

Option C. Direct antiglobulin test (DAT): This test is used to diagnose autoimmune hemolytic anemias, where the body's immune system attacks its own red blood cells. This is not the primary concern in this patient.

 

Option D. Bone marrow biopsy: While a bone marrow biopsy can reveal megaloblastic changes (characteristic of B12/folate deficiency), it is an invasive procedure and usually reserved for cases where the diagnosis is unclear or there is suspicion of other marrow disorders.

 

Educational objective:

 

In a patient with macrocytic anemia and a history suggestive of vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, the most helpful initial test is measuring serum B12 and folate levels.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease presents with fatigue and shortness of breath. His laboratory findings show a MCV 88 fL with a low reticulocyte production index (RPI < 2). Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anemia of chronic disease

 

Option D:

 

Chronic kidney disease is a classic cause of anemia of chronic disease, characterized by normocytic anemia with low RPI due to impaired erythropoietin production and iron utilization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Folate deficiency: Macrocytic anemia with high RPI.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: Microcytic anemia with low RPI.

 

Option C. Hemolytic anemia: Normocytic/macrocytic anemia with high RPI.

 

Educational objective:

 

Normocytic anemia with low RPI in the setting of chronic disease should prompt consideration of anemia of chronic disease.

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia (IDA)

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue and a normocytic anemia (MCV 90 fL). His iron studies show the following:

 

 

  • Serum iron: 30 mcg/dL (normal: 60-170 mcg/dL)
  • TIBC: 200 mcg/dL (normal: 240-450 mcg/dL)
  • Ferritin: 350 ng/mL (normal: 20-500 ng/mL)

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anemia of chronic disease (ACD)

 

Option A:

 

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD): This patient's presentation and lab values are consistent with ACD. The inflammatory response in rheumatoid arthritis disrupts iron metabolism, leading to low serum iron and TIBC, despite adequate iron stores (as indicated by the normal to elevated ferritin).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia (IDA): IDA would typically present with low serum iron, high TIBC, and low ferritin.

 

Option C. Thalassemia trait: This is a genetic condition causing microcytic anemia, not normocytic.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic anemia (SA): SA is less likely in this scenario as it often presents with elevated serum iron and ferritin.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Recognizing the distinct pattern of iron studies in anemia of chronic disease (low serum iron, low TIBC, and normal to elevated ferritin) is crucial for differentiating it from iron deficiency anemia.
  • In the setting of a chronic inflammatory condition like rheumatoid arthritis, anemia of chronic disease is a common consideration.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic alcoholism presents with fatigue, pallor, and a microcytic anemia. His iron studies reveal elevated iron, TIBC, and ferritin. Blood smear shows basophilic stippling. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sideroblastic anemia (SA)

 

Option B:

 

The elevated iron indices, presence of basophilic stippling, and history of alcohol abuse are consistent with sideroblastic anemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia (IDA): IDA would typically present with microcytic anemia but with low serum iron, high TIBC, and low ferritin.

 

Option C. Thalassemia trait: While thalassemia can also cause microcytic anemia, it would not typically cause elevated iron indices and basophilic stippling. Hemoglobin electrophoresis would be needed for definitive diagnosis.

 

Option D. Anemia of chronic disease (ACD): ACD usually presents as a normocytic anemia, though it can occasionally be microcytic. However, the iron indices in ACD would show low serum iron, low TIBC, and normal or elevated ferritin.

 

Educational objective:

 

the classic presentation and laboratory findings of sideroblastic anemia, particularly in the setting of chronic alcoholism:

 

  • Microcytic anemia: Small red blood cells (MCV < 80 fL)
  • Elevated iron indices: High serum iron, high total iron binding capacity (TIBC), and high ferritin
  • Basophilic stippling: Characteristic finding on peripheral blood smear
  • History of alcohol abuse: A risk factor for sideroblastic anemia.

questions.text: A patient with microcytic anemia fails to respond to oral iron supplementation. Which of the following should be considered in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

All of the mentioned conditions can present with microcytic anemia and may not respond to oral iron supplementation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Microcytic anemia with failed iron therapy suggests causes beyond iron deficiency. Consider thalassemia, sideroblastic anemia, or anemia of chronic disease.

choices.text: Normal serum iron, normal TIBC, and normal ferritin
Low serum iron, high TIBC, and low ferritin
Low serum iron, low TIBC, and high ferritin
High serum iron, normal TIBC, and high ferritin

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with heavy menstrual bleeding presents with fatigue and pallor. Her lab results show a microcytic anemia with an elevated red cell distribution width and a low reticulocyte count. Which of the following laboratory findings would MOST likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low serum iron, high TIBC, and low ferritin

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with iron deficiency anemia (IDA). In IDA, iron stores are depleted, leading to low serum iron and ferritin levels. The body attempts to compensate by increasing iron binding capacity (TIBC).

 

Educational objective:

 

The combination of microcytic anemia, elevated RDW, and low reticulocyte count with low serum iron, high TIBC, and low ferritin strongly suggests iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman of Mediterranean descent is found to have mild microcytic anemia on routine blood work. Her iron studies are normal, and hemoglobin electrophoresis reveals an elevated HbA2 level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta-thalassemia trait

 

Option C:

 

Microcytic anemia with normal iron studies and elevated HbA2 on electrophoresis are characteristic of beta-thalassemia trait.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia (IDA): While IDA is the most common cause of microcytic anemia, it would typically present with abnormal iron studies (low serum iron, low ferritin, and high total iron-binding capacity).

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease (ACD): ACD is typically normocytic, but can occasionally be microcytic. However, it would not typically cause elevated HbA2 levels on electrophoresis.

 

 

Option D. Alpha-thalassemia trait: Alpha thalassemia is another inherited disorder that can cause microcytic anemia, but it would not typically cause elevated HbA2 levels. Instead, it may be associated with an elevated HbH level or a normal hemoglobin electrophoresis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Beta-thalassemia is a common cause of microcytic anemia in individuals of Mediterranean descent. Hemoglobin electrophoresis is essential for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with fatigue, pallor, and jaundice. Her laboratory evaluation reveals a normocytic anemia with a positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT). Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of her anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immune-mediated hemolysis

 

Option C:

 

SLE is associated with autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which is characterized by normocytic anemia, positive DAT (indicating the presence of antibodies against red blood cells), and often jaundice due to increased bilirubin from red blood cell breakdown.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency: While iron deficiency can cause anemia, it typically results in a microcytic anemia (smaller red blood cells), not normocytic. Additionally, it would not explain the positive DAT or jaundice.

 

Option B. Folate deficiency: Folate deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia, which is a type of macrocytic anemia (larger red blood cells), not normocytic. It would also not explain the positive DAT or jaundice.

 

Option D. Impaired erythropoiesis: While SLE can sometimes affect the bone marrow and lead to impaired red blood cell production, it's less common than immune-mediated hemolysis and wouldn't explain the positive DAT.

 

Educational objective:

 

The combination of normocytic anemia, positive DAT, and jaundice in a patient with SLE strongly points toward immune-mediated hemolysis as the underlying cause.

questions.text: In a healthy adult male, the average daily iron absorption from dietary sources is approximately:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 mg

 

Option B:

 

Adult men typically require about ~1 mg of iron to be absorbed from the diet daily to maintain iron balance and replace losses.

 

Educational objective:

 

Iron Absorption of ~1mg/d is required from the diet in men, and 1.4mg/d in women to maintain homeostasis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with heavy menstrual periods complains of fatigue and brittle nails. Her lab results show a serum ferritin of 18 ng/mL and her TIBC was 370. Peripheral smear turns out to be normal. What is the MOST likely stage of iron deficiency in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative iron balance

 

Option A:

 

Negative iron balance: This is the earliest stage of iron deficiency. Iron stores are depleted, leading to low serum ferritin. However, at this stage, hemoglobin and hematocrit might still be within the normal range as the body has not yet reached the point of insufficient iron for red blood cell production. The elevated TIBC supports this diagnosis, reflecting the body's increased capacity to bind iron due to low stores. The normal peripheral smear indicates that red blood cell morphology has not yet been affected.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Iron-deficient erythropoiesis: In this stage, hemoglobin and hematocrit would likely start to decline.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency anemia: This stage is characterized by a clear drop in hemoglobin and hematocrit, along with microcytic and hypochromic red blood cells on peripheral smear.

 

Option D. Iron overload: This is the opposite of iron deficiency and is associated with elevated ferritin, normal to low TIBC, and other systemic complications.

 

Educational objective:

 

Early detection of iron deficiency through low serum ferritin is crucial for timely intervention and prevention of progression to iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following substances can IMPAIR the absorption of iron supplements?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antacids

 

Option D:

 

Antacids neutralize stomach acid, which is necessary for the conversion of ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), the form that is more readily absorbed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option (A, B, C): Vitamin C (in ascorbic acid and orange juice) and meat can all improve iron absorption.

 

Educational objective:

 

Patients taking iron supplements should avoid taking antacids concurrently, as this can reduce absorption.

choices.text: It is a common and effective oral iron supplement.
It should be taken on an empty stomach for optimal absorption.
It is often combined with ascorbic acid to enhance absorption.
It is the iron preparation with the highest elemental iron content.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with iron deficiency anemia is prescribed ferrous sulfate. Which of the following statements about ferrous sulphate is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is the iron preparation with the highest elemental iron content

 

Option D:

 

While ferrous sulfate( Iron content – 65mg) is a common and effective iron supplement, it does not have the highest elemental iron content. Ferrous fumarate( iron content - 107) has a slightly higher elemental iron content.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is a common and effective oral iron supplement: This is correct. Ferrous sulfate is widely used and effective for treating iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option B. It should be taken on an empty stomach for optimal absorption: This is also correct. Iron is best absorbed in an acidic environment, so taking it on an empty stomach or with vitamin C (which enhances acidity) improves absorption.

 

Option C. It is often combined with ascorbic acid to enhance absorption: This is true. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) helps convert ferric iron to ferrous iron, the form more readily absorbed by the body.

 

Educational objective:

 

Different iron preparations vary in their elemental iron content, but most are well absorbed and effective in treating iron deficiency anemia.

choices.text: They can safely receive any other parenteral iron formulation.
Oral iron therapy is the only safe option for them.
They should be referred for blood transfusion as needed.
They may be able to receive alternative parenteral iron formulations under close supervision.

questions.text: A patient has experienced anaphylaxis to iron dextran in the past. Which of the following statements is MOST accurate regarding their future management of iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) They may be able to receive alternative parenteral iron formulations under close supervision.

 

Option D:

 

While a history of anaphylaxis to iron dextran is a serious concern, other parenteral iron preparations with different chemical structures may be tolerated. However, these should be administered with caution, in a setting where anaphylaxis can be managed promptly.

 

Educational objective:

 

Patients with sensitivity to one iron preparation have been safely treated with other parenteral iron preparations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with severe iron deficiency anemia requires rapid replenishment of her iron stores. Which of the following parenteral iron preparations would provide the highest amount of iron in a single infusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ferric derisomaltose

 

Option D:

 

Ferric derisomaltose (Monoferric) can deliver up to 1000 mg of elemental iron in a single infusion, making it the parenteral iron preparation with the highest single-dose capacity. This makes it an attractive option for patients with severe iron deficiency who require rapid iron replenishment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ferric gluconate: Delivers a much lower dose of iron per infusion (125 mg).

 

Option B. Iron sucrose: Delivers a lower dose of iron per infusion (200 mg).

 

Option C. Ferric carboxymaltose: Delivers a lower dose of iron per infusion (750 mg).

 

Educational objective:

 

Ferric derisomaltose is a valuable option for patients with severe iron deficiency anemia who require rapid correction of iron stores, as it allows for the administration of a large dose of iron in a single infusion. However, it's important to consider potential side effects and contraindications before choosing this preparation.

choices.text: Within 24-48 hours of starting therapy
3-4 days after starting therapy
7-10 days after starting therapy
14-21 days after starting therapy

questions.text: A patient with iron deficiency anemia is started on oral iron supplementation. When would you expect to see the PEAK reticulocyte response, indicating that the bone marrow is actively producing new red blood cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7-10 days after starting therapy

 

Option C:

 

The peak reticulocyte response typically occurs within 1-1.5 weeks (7-10 days) after starting iron therapy. This indicates a robust response from the bone marrow to correct the anemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Within 24-48 hours of starting therapy: This is too soon to expect a peak response. It takes several days for the bone marrow to ramp up red blood cell production.

 

Option B. 3-4 days after starting therapy: While the reticulocyte count may start to rise within 3-4 days, the peak response is typically later.

 

Option D. 14-21 days after starting therapy: This is too late for the peak response. If there's no significant increase by this time, it could suggest a lack of response to therapy or an alternative diagnosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

The reticulocyte count is a valuable tool for monitoring the response to iron therapy in iron deficiency anemia. An increase in reticulocytes within 4-7 days and a peak response at 7-10 days are expected findings, indicating that the treatment is effective.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with microcytic anemia is given an iron tolerance test. Two hours after ingesting two iron tablets on an empty stomach, her serum iron level increases by 80 mcg/dL. What is the most likely interpretation of this result?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron malabsorption

 

Option B:

 

A normal iron tolerance test should result in an increase in serum iron of at least 100 mcg/dL. An increase of only 80 mcg/dL suggests impaired iron absorption.

 

Educational objective:

 

The iron tolerance test assesses the body's ability to absorb iron, and a rise of less than 100 mcg/dL suggests malabsorption.

questions.text: In infants who survive Hb Bart's hydrops fetalis, the approximate percentage that experiences neurodevelopmental delay is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20%

 

Option B:

 

The text states that "neurodevelopmental delay is present in 20% of survivors." This is a direct reference to the prevalence of neurodevelopmental delay in this specific population.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 10%: This underestimates the risk of neurodevelopmental delay in this population.

 

Option C. 30%: This overestimates the risk of neurodevelopmental delay in this population.

 

Option D. 40%: This is the percentage of survivors who experience growth retardation, not neurodevelopmental delay.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hb Bart’s hydrops fetalis is best prevented by screening couples at risk and antenatal diagnosis. Intrauterine therapy and perinatal intensive care have permitted survival of some infants with Hb Bart hydrops fetalis. As growth retardation affects ~40% and neurodevelopmental delay is present in 20% of survivors, prevention is the best approach.

questions.text: Which of the following alpha-globin gene arrangements is MOST likely to be associated with Hemoglobin H (HbH) disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) --/-α

 

Option D:

 

HbH disease is caused by the deletion or inactivation of three out of four alpha-globin genes. The genotype "--/-α" represents this condition, where one chromosome has both alpha-globin genes deleted, and the other chromosome has one alpha-globin gene deleted.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. αα/αα: α-thal. With Myelodysplasia - Mutations in ATRX; striking male predominance. Hematologic findings of HbH disease.

 

Option B. -α/αα: Represents the silent carrier state of alpha-thalassemia, with only one alpha-globin gene deleted. It typically doesn't cause significant clinical symptoms.

 

Option C. --/αα: Represents alpha-thalassemia trait, where two alpha-globin genes are deleted. This condition can lead to mild anemia but is not associated with HbH disease.

 

Educational objective:

 

The specific arrangement and number of alpha-globin gene deletions determine the severity of alpha-thalassemia. HbH disease, a moderate form of the condition, is caused by the deletion or inactivation of three out of four alpha-globin genes, represented by the genotype --/-α (other gene arrangement: αTα/- -, αTα/αTα)

choices.text: Prevention of RNA polyadenylation and reduced beta-globin production
Introduction of a stop codon and premature termination of translation
Creation of an alternative splice site in an intron
Total absence of beta-globin production

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with microcytic anemia is found to have a mutation in the 3' end-processing sequence of the beta-globin gene. Which of the following is the MOST likely consequence of this mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prevention of RNA polyadenylation and reduced beta-globin production

 

Option A:

 

 3' end-processing sequence mutations affect mRNA stability and lead to reduced but not absent beta-globin production (β+ thalassemia).

 

Educational objective:

 

Mutations in the 3' end-processing sequence are a specific type of mutation that can cause β+ thalassemia.

choices.text: Beta-zero (β0) thalassemia
Beta-plus (β+) thalassemia
Delta-beta (δβ) thalassemia
Hemoglobin Lepore thalassemia

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman of Mediterranean descent presents with mild anemia and microcytosis. Her iron studies are normal, and genetic testing reveals a change in the promoter region of the beta-globin gene. Which type of beta-thalassemia is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta-plus (β+) thalassemia

 

Option B:

 

Single nucleotide changes in the promoter region typically lead to reduced, but not absent, beta-globin production (β+ thalassemia).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Beta-zero (β0) thalassemia: Caused by severe mutations, not promoter changes, leading to complete absence of beta-globin production.

 

Option C. Delta-beta (δβ) thalassemia: Deletion of both delta and beta globin genes causes a different clinical picture.

 

Option D. Hemoglobin Lepore thalassemia: Rare condition caused by delta-beta globin gene fusion, not promoter mutations.

 

Educational objective:

 

Promoter mutations are a common cause of milder beta-thalassemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of mild anemia on routine blood work presents for a follow-up appointment. She reports good energy levels and denies any recent illnesses or blood loss. Her physical examination is unremarkable. A peripheral blood smear is shown in the image. Which of the following hematological conditions is MOST likely represented in this blood smear?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Beta-thalassemia intermedia

 

Option D:

 

The image shows target cells and marked variation in cell size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis), along with hypochromia (pale red blood cells) and microcytosis (small red blood cells). These are hallmark features of beta-thalassemia intermedia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: While also microcytic and hypochromic, it usually does not exhibit target cells or the degree of poikilocytosis seen here.

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Causes macrocytic (large red blood cell) anemia, not microcytic.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: Characterized by sickle-shaped red blood cells, which are not present in this image.

 

Educational objective:

 

The presence of target cells, anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, hypochromia and microcytosis in a blood smear strongly suggests beta-thalassemia intermedia.

questions.text: A 30-years-old male with a history of beta-thalassemia major has been receiving regular blood transfusions every 3 weeks to maintain a pre-transfusion hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL. Despite adherence to his transfusion schedule, he has recently developed fatigue, skin hyperpigmentation and hepatomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his new symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron overload

 

Option B:

 

Regular blood transfusions, while necessary to maintain hemoglobin levels in thalassemia major, inevitably lead to iron overload due to the lack of a physiological mechanism for excess iron excretion. Iron overload can manifest as fatigue, skin hyperpigmentation and hepatomegaly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Insufficient blood transfusions: The patient is adhering to the transfusion schedule, and his hemoglobin level is within the target range for thalassemia major. Thus, insufficient transfusions are unlikely to be the cause of his symptoms.

 

Option C. Folate deficiency: Folate deficiency typically causes megaloblastic anemia with macrocytic red blood cells. This is not consistent with the patient's history of thalassemia major or the presentation with microcytic anemia.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Similar to folate deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia, which is inconsistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Iron chelation therapy is crucial in patients with thalassemia major receiving regular transfusions to prevent iron overload and its associated complications.

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is administered orally for the treatment of iron overload in patients with thalassemia major?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both B and C

 

Option D:

 

Both deferiprone and deferasirox are oral iron chelators used in the management of iron overload in thalassemia major. They are easier to administer than the intravenous chelator, deferoxamine, and can improve patient compliance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deferoxamine: Deferoxamine is an intravenous iron chelator and requires subcutaneous infusion over several hours, making it less convenient for long-term use.

 

Educational objective:

 

Oral iron chelators like deferiprone and deferasirox have revolutionized the management of iron overload in thalassemia major by offering a more convenient and less invasive alternative to deferoxamine. Early and consistent chelation therapy is crucial for preventing iron-related complications and improving the quality of life for patients with thalassemia major.

choices.text: Positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) with anti-IgG specificity
Positive DAT with anti-C3d specificity
Positive DAT with anti-IgM specificity

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia and acrocyanosis that worsens in cold weather. Which of the following laboratory findings is most consistent with cold agglutinin syndrome (CAS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive DAT with anti-IgM specificity

 

Option C:

 

CAS is caused by IgM autoantibodies that bind to red blood cells at low temperatures, leading to agglutination and hemolysis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) with anti-IgG specificity and Option B. Positive DAT with anti-C3d specificity are more commonly associated with WAIHA.

 

Option D. Negative DAT: A negative DAT would not be expected in a patient with autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

A positive DAT with anti-IgM specificity is a key laboratory finding in the diagnosis of CAS.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of lymphoma presents with fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear shows spherocytes. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia (WAIHA)

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly, along with spherocytes on peripheral smear, is most consistent with WAIHA. The history of lymphoma increases the likelihood of WAIHA, as some types of lymphoma can trigger autoimmune responses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cold agglutinin disease (CAD): Primarily presents with acrocyanosis and anemia, and blood smear often reveals agglutination.

 

Option B. Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH): Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) is rare and typically presents with biphasic hemolysis and hemoglobinuria after cold exposure.

 

Option D. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA): Presents with schistocytes on peripheral smear and is associated with underlying conditions like thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) or hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

 

Educational objective:

 

WAIHA is the most common type of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and can be associated with underlying lymphoproliferative disorders like lymphoma
